sen.j: 忠房親王（ただふさしんのう、弘安8年（1285年）? - 貞和3年（1347年）7月 (旧暦)）は鎌倉時代の皇族。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Tadafusa (1285?-1347) was a member of the Imperial family in the Kamakura period.
Imperial Prince Tadafusa (1285? - 1347) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kamakura period.
Imperial Prince Tadafusa (1285? - around August, 1347) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 貞和3年7月を西暦に直して補足しました。

sen.j: 順徳天皇皇孫源彦仁の子で母は従一位関白二条師忠の娘。
sen.e: His father was MINAMOTO no Hikohito, an Imperial descendant of Emperor Juntoku, and his mother was a daughter of Morotada NIJO, the Juichii Kanpaku (Junior First Rank, the chief adviser to the Emperor)..
His father was MINAMOTO no Hikohito, an imperial descendant of Emperor Juntoku, and his mother was a daughter of Morotada NIJO, the Juichii Kanpaku (Junior First Rank, chief adviser to the Emperor).
His father was MINAMOTO no Hikohito, the grandchild of Emperor Juntoku, and his mother was the daughter of Morotada NIJO, a Juichii Kanpaku (Junior First Rank, chief adviser to the Emperor).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 祖父の岩倉宮忠成王（順徳天皇第五皇子）は、四条天皇崩御後に皇位継承の最有力者と目されながらも鎌倉幕府によって阻止されて、岩倉宮の宮号を賜る。
sen.e: Although his grandfather Iwakuranomiya Prince Tadanari (the fifth prince of Emperor Juntoku) was regarded as the most likely candidate to succeed the Imperial Throne after the death of Emperor Shijo, he was defeated in the race for deciding the next heir due to the obstruction by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), instead granted the reigning name of Iwakuranomiya.

Although his grandfather, Iwakuranomiya Prince Tadanari (the fifth prince of Emperor Juntoku), was regarded as the most likely candidate for succession to the Imperial Throne after the death of Emperor Shijo, he was defeated in the race to decide the next heir due to obstruction by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and was instead granted the reigning name of Iwakuranomiya.

Although Tadafusa's grandfather, Iwakuranomiya Prince Tadanari (the fifth prince of Emperor Juntoku), was regarded as the most likely candidate for succession to the Imperial Throne after the death of Emperor Shijo, he was defeated in the race to decide the next heir due to obstruction by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and was instead granted the reigning name of Iwakuranomiya.

sen.j: 親王は父彦仁がそうであるように親王宣下を受けるまでは源姓を名乗っており、源忠房とも。
sen.e: Similar to his father Hikohito, the Imperial prince had used the family name of Minamoto until he was given the title of Imperial Prince, so he was also called MINAMOTO no Tadafusa.
Like his father Hikohito, the Imperial Prince used the family name of Minamoto until he was given the title of Imperial Prince, so he was also called MINAMOTO no Tadafusa.
Like Tadafusa's father Hikohito, the Imperial Prince used the family name of Minamoto until he was given the title of Imperial Prince, so he was also called MINAMOTO no Tadafusa.

sen.j: 従一位関白二条兼基の娘を妃とする。
sen.e: He married a daughter of Kanemoto NIJO, the Juichii Kanpaku.
He married a daughter of Kanemoto NIJO, the Juichii Kanpaku.
He married a daughter of Kanemoto NIJO, the Juichii Kanpaku.

sen.j: 王子には源彦善がいるが、四辻宮尊雅王及びその子源善成が実は忠房親王の王子であるとの説も存在する。
sen.e: He had a prince MINAMOTO no Hikoyoshi, however, another theory suggests that Yotsutsujinomiya Prince Songa and his son MINAMOTO no Yoshinari were the princes of Imperial Prince Tadafusa in fact.
He had a prince, MINAMOTO no Hikoyoshi, but another theory suggests that Yotsutsujinomiya Prince Songa and his son, MINAMOTO no Yoshinari, were the princes of Imperial Prince Tadafusa.
He had a prince, MINAMOTO no Hikoyoshi, but another theory suggests that Prince Yotsutsujinomiya Songa and his son, MINAMOTO no Yoshinari, were actually the princes of Imperial Prince Tadafusa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。「Yotsutsujinomiya Prince Songa」を「Prince Yotsutsujinomiya Songa」に訂正しました。

sen.j: 兄弟に承鎮法親王、守子内親王、玄覚がいる。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Shochinho, Imperial Princess Moriko and Genkaku were his siblings.
His siblings were Imperial Prince Shochinho and the imperial princesses Moriko and Genkaku.
His siblings were Imperial Prince Shochinho, Imperial Princess Moriko, and Genkaku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 親王は後宇多天皇に寵愛され猶子となり、権中納言に取り立てられる。
sen.e: Favored by Emperor Gouda, the imperial prince was adopted by the emperor and promoted to the Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor).
Favored by Emperor Gouda, the Imperial Prince was adopted by the Emperor and promoted to the Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor).
Favored by Emperor Gouda, the Imperial Prince was adopted by the Emperor and promoted to the Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor).

sen.j: その後親王宣下を受けるが、これが昨今の皇位継承問題 (平成)において臣籍に産まれた人物が皇籍についた事が旧皇族復帰を推す勢力に先例として重要視されている。
sen.e: The grant of Imperial Prince title to him afterward is thought much of and regarded as a precedent by the group supporting the resurrection of the former Imperial family to solve the latest issue on deciding the successor of the Imperial Throne in the Heisei period, because it meant a commoner entered the Imperial family.

Subsequently, the granting of the title Imperial Prince has been considered at length and regarded as a precedent by the group supporting the resurrection of the former Imperial Family in order to solve the latest issue on deciding the successor of the Imperial Throne in the Heisei period, because it meant a commoner had entered the Imperial Family.

Subsequently, he was given the title of Imperial Prince and in the latest issue on deciding the successor of the Imperial Throne in the Heisei period, this has been valued as a precedent by the group supporting the resurrection of the former Imperial Family, as it meant a commoner had entered the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 尚、猶子とは皇子に準じた扱いとする事だが、皇室について用いた始まりは『職原鈔』に忠房親王が後宇多院の猶子となす旨記された事に始まるという。
sen.e: The decision that "The adopted child of an emperor is treated as an Imperial Prince" is believed to have been put into practice in the Imperial family for the first time when "Shokugensho" (a book on Japanese government officials) stipulated that Imperial Prince Tadafusa was the adopted child of Gouda-in (the retired Emperor Gouda).
sen.cmt: 猶子とは皇子に準じた扱いとする，の意味がわかりません。
sen.e: The decision that "the Emperor's adopted child is treated as the Imperial Prince" is believed to have been put into practice in the Imperial Family for the first time when "Shokugensho" (a book on Japanese government officials) asserted that Imperial Prince Tadafusa was the adopted child of Gouda-in (the retired Emperor Gouda).

The word Yushi (猶子, the adopted child) means to treat like an Imperial Prince and it is believed to have been put into practice in the Imperial Family for the first time when "Shokugensho" (a book on Japanese government officials) asserted that Imperial Prince Tadafusa was the Yushi of Goudain (the Retired Emperor Gouda).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Gouda-inをGoudainに訂正しました。Retired大文字にしました。

sen.j: 尤も言葉としては漢語であり『礼記』に見える。
sen.e: However, this is originated in "Raiki (book on rites)" written in Chinese.
However, this idea originated in "Raiki (book on rites)," which was written in Chinese.
However, the word Yushi is one of Chinese origin, and referred in "Raiki" (book on rites).
sen.cmt: 「猶子」という言葉についての説明と思われるため、表現を少し変えました。
